awd_titl_txt: Along Strike Variation of Seismic Moment Release and Coupling Along Oceanic Transform Faults
awd_abstract_narration:
Earth's tectonic plates that are created at mid ocean ridge spreading centers are dissected by a global network of oceanic transform faults that offset the mid-ocean ridge segments. The motion along these oceanic transform faults is lateral and they are analogs to continental transform faults. Continental transform faults, such as the San Andreas Fault in California, pose a serious risk to population centers and a better understanding of their seismic behavior would considerably aid hazard estimation in high-risk population centers near these faults. While oceanic transforms are remote making it difficult to study their seismological behavior, the material properties of oceanic crust and mantle are much more homogenous than continental lithosphere. Furthermore, large earthquakes that periodically rupture the same fault patches have recently been identified on some oceanic transform faults. These repeating fault patches could be considered a laboratory for studying earthquake nucleation and rupture. In this project, we will study a global set of oceanic transforms to find out how common repeating rupture patches are. The project will characterize their size and distribution, and identify parameters such as plate rate, temperature or geometrical fault zone complexity that might affect fault behavior.  On broader impacts, it is anticipated that results from oceanic transforms will lead to improved seismic hazard estimates of continental transforms. Results from the project will also guide selection of which oceanic transform faults to study in the future including the placement of ocean bottom seismometers. The project will support two early career researchers and a female graduate student.

The remoteness of oceanic transform faults has hindered a systematic, detailed study of their along strike seismic behavior. Prior studies estimated the average behavior over entire oceanic transforms and found that a considerable amount of the plate motions is accommodated by aseismic creep. However, recent studies reveal spatially highly variable seismic moment release and identify fault patches where large earthquakes occur with quasi-periodic recurrence times. Large earthquakes account for the full plate motion and fault patches on which they occur are termed fully coupled. Fully coupled patches seem to be surrounded by regions of low coupling, where fault motion is accommodated mainly by aseismic creep. This project will study a global set of 30 oceanic transform faults spanning a wide range of plate motion rates, fault length and morphological complexity to determine the ubiquity of repeating rupture patches and along-strike variations of seismic coupling. Data for the project will be drawn from readily available global earthquake catalogs, seismic waveforms and high-resolution bathymetry to relate the spatial seismic moment release pattern to seismicity and fault zone geometry. The project will provide a first order characterization of parameters that affect size and likelihood of occurrence of fully coupled patches such as plate rate, thermal structure and fault zone geometrical and material complexity. The existence of strong fault patches with repeating earthquakes would indicate that strong and weak parts of a fault zone remain in place over many seismic cycles. The boundaries between strong and weak patches may control rupture nucleation and arrest and knowing their location would allow targeted studies to search for potential changes in seismicity and fault zone properties preceding large ruptures. Overall, results from this project will lead to a better understanding of different modes of seismic energy release and earthquake ruptures and are potentially transferrable to the structurally more complex continental transform faults.

por.por_cntn:
Organization: University of South Florida

Grant Period: 08/01/2017-07/31/2021

PI: Jochen Braunmiller, co-PI: Glenn Thompson

Earth's surface is composed of about 20 major and minor tectonic plates. The plates are relatively rigid, and most earthquakes occur at plate boundaries where two plates move relative to each other. The plate motion rates, i.e., how fast plates move relative to each other, are fairly well known, for example from high-resolution GPS and other data. The main questions that we addressed in this project are: (1) How much of the predicted motions are accounted for by earthquakes, (2) How variable is the contribution of earthquakes along a plate boundary, and (3) Do large earthquakes rupture the same fault patch repeatedly. The ratio of the earthquake contribution to predicted motion is called seismic coupling and, long-term, varies from 0 to 1. Large earthquakes rupturing the same fault patch are called repeating earthquakes.

Our study targets are transform faults in the oceans. At transforms, two plates on either side of the fault move laterally relative to each other. The most famous example is the San Andreas Fault in California. We study transform faults in the oceans because the composition of the outermost shell of the Earth is more homogeneous in oceans than on continents, which makes these faults ideal targets to study earthquake physics and rupture behavior.

Our primary study targets were oceanic transform faults in the Atlantic Ocean. Motion along these faults is considered slow and varies from about 14 to 33 mm/yr. We used a global earthquake catalog, which provides earthquake locations and size (magnitude) and covers approximately the last 60 years. We converted earthquake sizes to slip on a fault patch, repeated the process for all earthquakes along a plate boundary, and then summed the slip for all fault patches. In previous studies, slip was summed and averaged over the entire plate boundary. In our approach, we place the slip of each earthquake roughly at the location where it occurred, which results in a slip distribution that varies along the plate boundary.

Our main findings are: (1) On average, earthquakes at oceanic transforms account only for about 15% of the expected plate motions; that means most motion must occur as continuous or sporadic creep. (2) The amount of slip due to earthquakes varies laterally along all transform faults studied. (3) Fully coupled fault segments and repeating earthquakes seem to be restricted to transform faults where earthquakes, on average, contribute significantly to predicted plate motions.

The attached figure is an example from the Oceanographer transform fault in the Central Atlantic Ocean. The left panel shows the distance along the fault with fault ends marked by triangles and the time when an earthquake occurred. Colored circles are large earthquakes with magnitude of 6 and above, which define two adjacent fault segments (shown in green and orange). All large earthquakes in the last 60 years occurred at one of these two segments. Large earthquakes seem to repeat but the inter-event times are not constant. The right panel shows slip due to earthquakes. The red line ?Full? indicates the amount of slip that corresponds to the plate motions. Earthquakes roughly account for the predicted plate motions for the segments with repeating earthquakes. For other parts of the fault, creep dominates.

The Oceanographer fault is an example where repeating earthquakes occur on fully coupled segments. However, most faults studied (~40 in total) do not have fully coupled fault segments or repeating earthquake patches. This implies that fault creep must play a dominant role in plate boundary processes (at least at transform faults).

If fault creep contributes significantly to deformation at other plate boundaries too could imply that seismic hazard estimates based simply on plate motion rates may overestimate the hazard as some or most of the predicted motion will be accommodated by slow, aseismic creep. In contrast, for fully couple segments almost all of the relative motion is likely released during large earthquakes posing a significant seismic hazard. Identifying fully coupled segments and obtaining bounds for repeat intervals might thus be a highly valuable exercise to reduce risk.

Two graduate students were engaged in the project gaining valuable research experience.


Last Modified: 02/28/2022
Modified by: Jochen Braunmiller

Image
  • Left: Earthquakes (circles) along strike of the transform vs. time. Colored: magnitude M6+ earthquakes; colored boxes: repeating earthquake patches. Right: Seismic slip distribution along strike relative to full plate motion rate (red line). The repeating earthquake patches are fully coupled
    J. Braunmiller
    Copyrighted
    Jochen Braunmiller
    Oceanographer transform: Repeating earthquakes at fully coupled fault patches
